column5: In 1419, Joan of Navarre was imprisoned at Pevensey Castle after her confessor accused her of plotting to kill King Henry V with witchcraft. Her fortune was seized, and she remained in captivity until her release in 1422.
Elizabeth was in sanctuary at Westminster Abbey when accusations of witchcraft were being publicly used against her and her family.

In 1441, Eleanor Cobham was accused of treasonable necromancy after consulting astrologers who predicted King Henry VIâ€™s illness, leading to a highly publicized trial. Found guilty of witchcraft and conspiracy, she was forced to perform public penance, divorced from her husband, and condemned to life imprisonment.
Evidence of Jacquetta's witchcraft was brought to Warwick Castle - it was a small metal man-of-arms, broken in half and fastend with wire!
